title: Reforms risk increasing geographical imbalance in EU staff, auditors say
text:
Flags of the European Union flying outside European Parliament | Frederick Florin/AFP via Getty Images Reforms risk increasing geographical imbalance in EU staff, auditors say Auditors conclude cost savings ‘overshadowed by their impact on the workforce.’

EU staff reforms produced significant cost savings but reduced the Union’s attractiveness as an employer, the European Court of Auditors concluded in a report Tuesday.

The report, which focuses on the European Commission, assessed the impact of a 2014 EU staff reform package that led to a 5 percent reduction in staff posts and an increase in the retirement age from 63 to 66, as well as temporary pension and salary freezes.

The auditors found the reforms created “significant savings” for the EU budget, estimated at €4.2 billion for the period 2014-2020 and €19.2 billion from 2014 to 2064. While the report notes an improved link between pay, grade and responsibility, as well as advances in gender balance, it points to challenges arising from the reforms.

“Savings generated from the 2014 staff reforms go beyond expectations, but they are overshadowed by their impact on the workforce,” said Pietro Russo, the member of the European Court of Auditors responsible for the report. “The HR implications of the cost-saving measures were not without negative consequences.”

Specifically, the report found that changes in working conditions “have reduced the relative attractiveness of working for the EU to some nationalities that are already under-represented.”

While the report notes an improved link between pay, grade and responsibility, as well as advances in gender balance, it points to challenges arising from the reforms.

The auditors found Belgians are most represented in the Commission, while British and German citizens are least represented among EU employees. Polish nationals are underrepresented in intermediate and higher grades, while Spanish, French and Dutch employees are underrepresented in intermediate grades.

The auditors noted that following the implementation of the reforms, “surveys show a decline in the overall perception of the Commission as an organisation that cares about staff well-being,” and that “almost one third of Commission staff feel that they have an unacceptable workload.”

The reforms have contributed to an increase in the proportion of contract staff from 20 percent to 24 percent, while the proportion of official and temporary staff has declined.

They also contributed to an aging Commission workforce, with the auditors noting that the Commission “may need to update its policies for training, well-being, career development and knowledge management.”

The auditors noted that the overall sickness rate in the Commission has increased between 2012 and 2017, most markedly in the Commission's Directorate-General for Justice and Consumers, where the average sick leave days per person increased from 10.3 days on average in 2013-2015 to 18.9 in 2017.
